qas.question: What detail of Jesus's Crucifiction was only found in Matthew's Gospel?
Which gospel mentioned the time of Crucifiction?
Who did Jesus talk to in the Gospel of Luke?

answers.text: words to the women who were mourning

qas.question: What gospel talks about breaking Jesus' legs?
What prophecy was fulfilled by the piercing of Jesus' side?
What time did the Romans decide to guard the tomb of Jesus?
Who did the Roman soldiers speak to when they were in mourning?
What did one Roman soldier do to chastise the other?
What did the Roman soldiers do to celebrate their victory?
What did the Romans use when one of their soldiers had an injury?

context: There are several details that are only found in one of the gospel accounts. For instance, only Matthew's gospel mentions <a0_0>an earthquake<a0_0/>, resurrected saints who went to the city and that Roman soldiers were assigned to guard the tomb, while <a1_0>Mark<a1_0/> is the only one to state the actual time of the crucifixion (<b5_0>the third hour, or 9 am<b5_0/>) and the centurion's report of Jesus' death. The Gospel of Luke's unique contributions to the narrative include Jesus' <a2_0>words to <b6_0>the women<b6_0/> who were mourning<a2_0/>, one criminal's <b7_0>rebuke<b7_0/> of the other, the reaction of the multitudes who left <b8_0>"beating their breasts"<b8_0/>, and the women preparing <b9_0>spices and ointments<b9_0/> before resting on the Sabbath. <a3_0>John<a3_0/> is also the only one to refer to the request that the legs be broken and the soldier's subsequent piercing of Jesus' side (as fulfillment of <a4_0>Old Testament prophecy<a4_0/>), as well as that Nicodemus assisted Joseph with burial.
